description: CompTIA Security+ professionals help to implement, administer and maintain a secure computing environment for any organization. The certification is designed for those with a few years of experience in IT administration with a focus on security that want to help protect and secure their network. Viewers will hear about different topics and objectives discussed in this course including different areas of security, threats and vulnerabilities, cryptography, and other additional topics and will attain knowledge and skills to identify security issues, to mitigate and deter threats, to apply security controls and implement and maintain an organization’s security policies.
descriptionMD: _CompTIA Security+_ professionals help to implement, administer and maintain a secure computing environment for any organization. The certification is designed for those with a few years of experience in IT administration with a focus on security that want to help protect and secure their network. Viewers will hear about different topics and objectives discussed in this course including different areas of security, threats and vulnerabilities, cryptography, and other additional topics and will attain knowledge and skills to identify security issues, to mitigate and deter threats, to apply security controls and implement and maintain an organization’s security policies. __This course has been CAQC'd and qualifies for CEU credits. [Click here](https://itpro.tv/comptia-partnership) to get an exam voucher discount.__
name: CompTIA Security+
subtitle: Vendor-neutral IT Security

episodes.description: CompTIA Security+ professionals help to implement, administer and maintain a secure computing environment for any organization.  Earning the Security+ certification is foundational for anyone who wants to start a network security career. Learners will have attain knowledge and skills to identify security issues, to mitigate and deter threats, to apply security controls and implement and maintain an organization's security policies.  Many organizations that handle sensitive financial or medical data seek the skills of CompTIA Security+ professional when filling IT position.
episodes.title: Introduction to Security+

episodes.description: How a network is designed can have a big role to play in the strength of security behind it. Viewers will hear about elements and components of network design that security will need to be implemented in, how one can implement an in-depth layered defense to a network, and different devices that are part of the design that can help defend a network like routers, firewalls, subnets, and VLANs as well as hear about cloud computing and how it can be securely used in today’s businesses.
episodes.title: Network Design

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike take a look at the protocols and ports every Security+ candidate should be familiar with. They discuss the associated technology with each port and protocol and how it relates to the OSI model.
episodes.title: Protocols and Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Ronnie begin to take a look at some of the most common security devices that are implemented across a production network.  They emphasize where devices are generally used on the network as well as describe the devices basic security features and uses.
episodes.title: Securing Network Devices

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike take a look at the solutions and technologies available to network administrators for securing system networks such as rule-based management and access control lists. They go on to discuss common security issues with wireless networking such as WEP and antenna placement and how to mitigate them.
episodes.title: Network Administration Principles

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee introduce Risk Concepts that all IT security professionals should understand.  They define what is risk and the general types of risk.  They also show the cycle of risk analysis that is constant and not just a single process but something that is done continuously.  With that understanding that risk need to be identified and analyzed, the team tells us how to appropriately deal with risk that arise within our organization.
episodes.title: Risk Concepts

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue with the concepts by giving examples and demonstration of risk calculations: ALE, SLE and ARO.  Cherokee also describes the terms MTTR, MTTF, MTBF, RPO and RTO with some examples.  The team explain the different controls that are in place to help with risk management:  Technical, Operational, and Management controls too.  Lastly, Cherokee describes some of the different ways in which security policies help to reduce risk within an organization.
episodes.title: Risk Concepts Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike take a look at risk management and incident response. They begin with discussing the implications of integrating systems with third parties such as interoperability agreements and data ownership. They go on to discuss incident response procedures such as incident identification and mitigation steps. They conclude with describing risk assessments and tabletop exercises.
episodes.title: Security Management Practices

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike take a look at security awareness and security controls. They begin with discussing the importance of awareness training among users such as information classification and data labeling and handling. They also explain various physical and environmental controls such as HVAC systems, fire suppression systems and alarms and barricades.
episodes.title: Physical Security & Awareness

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee introduce some of the different risk management Strategies.  They explain some of the different types of security policies used and their importance to the overall security strategy.  They emphasize DLP, data loss protection as a key policy in today’s security posture with the advent of BYOD.  More and more devices are onboard and off boarded that need to be sanitized of data existing before use and after use.  Other strategies that are policy driven are also discussed.
episodes.title: Risk Management Strategies

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee introduce some of the way to enforce the policies that are put in place for organizations.  They review the concepts of automated policies for DLP through device loss or theft.  They describe the use of audit policies and user permission issues and even mention some of the technology controls.   Also,  they discuss the importance of change management process as part of risk management.  Lastly, they describe the steps of Incident Management that security professionals must adhere to when security incident occurs.
episodes.title: Risk Management Strategies Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee take a look at the basic forensic procedures that an IT security professional should understand.  They discuss each procedure and describe the purpose and it’s importance in the forensic process.  The describe the basic evidence gathering that must occur when a computer security incident happens for a company.  Even though many may not be a forensic expert, according to the team, every Security+ professional should be familiar with the process to insure that computer evidence is not collected haphazardly so a legal case is not made.
episodes.title: Basic Forensic Procedures

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee help identify the common security goals of   every security control implemented.  They describe each element of the CIA triad and then describes some of the different security controls that help to meet each goal.  Along with the CIA triad, security also has the goal of human safety as well. They emphasize reasons to each and what they do.
episodes.title: Security Goals

episodes.description: In this episode, Nathan and Ronnie describe implementing security controls in content. They describe the use of procedures and practices used to mitigate security risks, next Nathan and Ronnie discuss the benefits of knowing and using basic forensic process responses and they close the show describing the basic controls used to help meet the security goals of an organization.
episodes.title: Security Contexts

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee discuss some of the different techniques to mitigate and deter security incidences.  They show how to use the event viewer to access different logs in a Windows machine and discuss the ways they help identify when and possibly what security incident occurred.  Also, they discuss additional methods much as implementing IPS and/or IDS into our networks while using the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security to demonstrate andIPS.  Using a wireless access point, Cherokee shows how to setup MAC filtering and describes using 802.1x for authentication as a security mitigation technique.  Lastly, they briefly mention device hardening techniques to help.
episodes.title: Analyze Mitigation and Deterrents

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee take a look at the various attacks.  They briefly describe several attack methods such as DoS and DDos that are designed not as an attack breaching the systems target but a way to deny access to resources targeted.  They also describe the nature of man in the middle attacks and the use of replay attacks.  Cherokee describes the MiTM as the method used to get data and the Replay attack as taking data learned during the MiTMand using it.  Also addressed by the team, are spoofing and some of the different types of Phishing attacks and SPAM.
episodes.title: Summarizing Various Attacks

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue from part 1.  They elaborate on different attacks designed to breach applications settings and privileges.  Also the use of poisoning to help redirect the response from systems to the attacker are identified.  The team goes on to describe some of the different application and access attacks too.  These are some of the password attacks as well as application attacks such as client side attacks and URL squatting too.
episodes.title: Summarizing Various Attacks Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee discuss some of the different social engineering attacks that CompTIA Security+ professionals need to be able to identify and mitigate.  They describe the most common social engineering attacks such as Shoulder Surfing, Dumpster Diving and Tailgating.  Cherokee share several different news worthy incidents where social engineering was the main form of attack and their outcomes too.  Also the team talks about the reasons for its effectiveness and how to mitigate these attacks.
episodes.title: Social Engineering Attacks

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don delve into the world of vulnerability and penetration testing. They introduce various tools used to determine the ports and systems in use as well as baiting attackers away from critical infrastructure through the use of honeypots and honeynets. They conclude with a brief discussion on the penetration testing process and the different levels in can be performed at.
episodes.title: Vulnerability Scanning

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes help us to identify some of the most common wireless attacks that IT professionals will  have to face in their job skills.  They discuss some of the common attacks and they demonstrates the use of packet sniffing.  These are foundational skills in a wireless attacks.  The guy also talk about the context in which we’ll see things like Rogue Access Points and demonstrate the use of Evil Twins on Wireless networks.
episodes.title: Wireless Attacks

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes help us to identify some of the more aggressive types of attacks on wireless technologies. These types of attacks typically require more skill and knowledge to accomplish.  We see this in the demonstrations that Wes presents on the reply attack as well as in bluejacking and bluesnarfing.  He demonstrates the capture of initialization vectors and attempts break WEP encryption doing so.
episodes.title: Wireless Attacks Part 2

episodes.description: "In this episode, Ronnie and Wes explain the some of the different types of injection attacks.  These attacks are normally carried out against web servers connected to the internet, according to the guys.  They also take a moment to talk about how to deal with these types of attacks as well.
episodes.title: Application Attacks

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes continue to look at different application attacks.  This time, they begin with taking a look at how someone can gain access to directories beyond the web server.  They also describe the use of attachments, cookies and session hijacking to compromise machines.
episodes.title: Application Attacks Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode you will learn what penetration testing is, who performs penetrations tests and with what tools and techniques. Ronnie also shows sites that outline regulation guidelines. Once a threat has been verified security controls must be bypasssed. Next, a pentester will actively test the security controls and potentially exploit the vulnerability to help the client identify and address the vulnerabilities.
episodes.title: Pentesting vs Vulnerability Scanning

episodes.description: This episode is a continuation where we compare and contrast the details of penetration testing versus vulnerability testing. We see the difference between active and passive methods.  We learn that the first step is to identify the vulnerability, then identify vulnerabilities and security controls and common misconfigurations. Next, we look at some options such as intrusive vs non-intrusive or credentialed or non-credentialed. Ronnie also shows us some regulatory guidelines. Lastly, you will see different testing models white box, gray box and black box.
episodes.title: Pentesting vs Vulnerability Scanning Part 2

episodes.description: In the episode Ronnie and Cherokee begin to discuss numerous application security controls. We see how important it is to stress test your applications with fuzzing tools prior to release and after any major changes or updates. They also cover some secure coding concepts such as error and exception handling, input validation, and standards for different platforms.
episodes.title: Explain App Security Controls

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don explain the solution available to security professionals to help ensure data is secure on host systems, in static environments and the tools to do so. They discuss host security concepts such as host-based intrusion detection systems and OS hardening. They also provide insight on how to protect our data when dealing with embedded systems from SCADA systems to game consoles.
episodes.title: App, Data, and Host Security Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee continue to explain application security controls. Ronnie breaks down Cross-site scripting and Cross-site Request Forgery (XSRF) attacks and offer solutions to help mitigate those types of attacks from occurring. You will also see the importance of determining an application configuration baseline in addition to ways to harden applications.
episodes.title: Explain App Security Controls Part 2

episodes.description: This is a part three and you will see Ronnie and Cherokee continue to explain application security controls. They begin with outlining SQL versus NoSQL databases. You will the types and structure formats the different styles have to offer. You will also learn about different types of validation checking, including server versus client side validation.
episodes.title: Explain App Security Controls Part 3

episodes.description: {Description}In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee take a look into host based security.  This part of implementing defense in depth, according to Cherokee.  They take the time to show why it’s important and some of the tools and techniques that part of implementing host security.   Using a Windows 10 machine, they show some of the considerations of using Anti-malware and also the Windows Firewall profile and even some of the granularity of the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security!
episodes.title: Host Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue with additional considerations for host security.   They pick up with some of the additional OS hardening techniques by stopping or disabling services, removing unused programs and removing temporary network shared folders from the host machines if unused.  Lastly, they review some of the considerations when considering virtualization host and virtualized guest security.
episodes.title: Host Security Part 2

episodes.description: {description}In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee introduce the topic of mobile security.  They discuss some of the areas of concerns that BYOD, Bring Your Own Device, brings to network security.  They describe some of the ramification of data ownership, SLA, patch management and even anti-malware solutions.  Also of concern are the areas of privacy and legal concerns about keeping private and company data secure.  Lastly they also address some of the policies that help and demonstrate the use of Full Device encryption on a smartphone.
episodes.title: Mobile Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue the mobile security show previously recorded.  They pickup with some of the other features that can help secure the smart phone.  They discuss some of the different aspects of application control and mobile device management systems that are available for enforcing company security policies regardless of where those devices are in the world.  They also briefly describe the application security aspects that must be considered by a company’s security team before adding software to whitelists.
episodes.title: Mobile Security Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don take a look at identity management in the form of authentication, authorization, and access control. They compare various authentication services such as RADIUS, Kerberos and SAML. They also discuss concepts to provide authentication with various examples of access controls. They conclude with discussing some best practices with administering account management.
episodes.title: Access and Identity Management

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee begin to discuss available authentications services. In this episode we see examples of AAA ( Authentication, Authorization and Accounting) servers. First, they take a look at RADIUS (Remote Access Dial-in User Service) and see why it is a viable option altho it has been around a while. They then describe Cisco's TACACS+ (Terminal Access Controller Access Control System) and cover details that may help you decide which to implement.
episodes.title: Compare Authentication Services

episodes.description: This is episode is a continuation where Ronnie and Cherokee delve further into comparing authentication services. You will see Kerberos, LDAP, XTACACS, SAML and Secure LADP explained so one would be able to choose the right service.
episodes.title: Compare Authentication Services Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee help to understand access control.  They describe the basic authentication factors and help with Identity concepts.  Cherokee describes the concepts of what we use for identity and how authentication ties into identity.  The team also shows some of the different authentication protocols and controls can be used to implement this aspect of security.
episodes.title: Understand Access Control

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee take a look into some of the different authorization methods that are available to a security professional.  They discuss principle of least privilege, Discretionary Access Control and Mandatory Access Control along with Role and Rule based Access control.  Along with those authorization controls they describe the use of separation of duties and time of day restrictions.
episodes.title: Understand Access Control Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Cherokee and Ronnie explain the importance of credential management. They discuss different ways you can apply controls. User assigned privileges may work well in small environments but Cherokee shows how to navigate Active Directory to simplify administration on a larger scale.
episodes.title: Configure Account Management Controls

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don take a look at cryptography concepts. They explain the differences between the various types while offering a demo of steganography. They breakdown the cryptographic methods outlined in the exam objectives. They also demonstrate PKI and working with certificates.
episodes.title: Cryptography

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel cover a variety of topics that pertain to the Security+ exam. Here they cover application security, hypervisor host security, file permissions, user accounts and identity management, and cryptography systems like RIPEMD, Bcrypt and Public Key Infrastructures(PKI) Registration Authority(RA).
episodes.title: Additional Information
